title: PLAINTIFF'S REPLY IN SUPPORT OF MOTION TO COMPEL FURTHER RESPONSES TO INTERROGATORIES

arguments.paragraph: Defendant's opposition mischaracterizes the record and ignores well-established principles of discovery law. The record demonstrates unequivocally that Defendant has failed to provide code-compliant responses to Plaintiff's interrogatories.

arguments.text: Defendant Still Has Not Provided Code-Compliant Responses

arguments.paragraph: The opposition does not provide a single substantive response to the interrogatories at issue. Instead, Defendant attempts to hide behind boilerplate objections. Each objection lacks the detailed factual showing required by Elk Hills Petroleum, Inc. v. Superior Court, 220 Cal.App.3d 627 (1990).

arguments.text: The Privilege and Work Product Claims Are Unfounded

arguments.paragraph: Defendant claims privilege and work product protection without providing a privilege log or factual basis for the claim. The documents sought are not protected by attorney-client privilege because they predate the retention of counsel and do not relate to legal advice.

Defendant cites no authority for its position. By contrast, California courts consistently hold that vague, conclusory objections are improper and subject to a motion to compel. See Hartbrodt v. State, 118 Cal.App.4th 1674 (2004).

Plaintiff respectfully urges the Court to grant this reply and to compel Defendant to provide complete and code-compliant responses to Interrogatories, Set One, within ten days of this order. If Defendant continues to assert objections, it must provide a detailed privilege log for each document withheld.

pos.document_title: Reply in Support of Motion to Compel Further Responses to Interrogatories
